metadata.case_name: Union of India v. Respondent (Sub-Inspector of Police)

facts.text: Respondent appointed as Sub-Inspector of Police by Inspector-General of Police in Sind before partition of India.
Respondent posted in Delhi by Deputy Inspector-General of Police Delhi after migration to India.
In 1949, respondent posted as Sub-Inspector of Police in Police Station Daryaganj, Delhi.
Departmental enquiry launched against respondent in 1949 on charge of acceptance of bribe in connection with a criminal case.

Diwanchand Dhatia employed as Deputy Superintendent of Police in City of Delhi until April 1949, retired that month, re-employed from date of retirement as Deputy Superintendent of Police, Enforcement Department.
Enquiry against respondent conducted by Diwanchand Dhatia after his retirement but during re-employment period.
Respondent found guilty of the charge.
Respondent dismissed from service by order dated December 8, 1949 passed by Jagannath, Superintendent of Police in Delhi Police Force.
Respondent filed suit challenging dismissal on January 12, 1954 in court of Subordinate Judge Delhi.
Union of India filed written statement disputing contentions.
Subordinate Judge framed issues on competency of Jagannath to pass dismissal order and Diwanchand Bhatia to conduct enquiry, decreed suit in favour of plaintiff.
Decree upheld in appeal by Additional District Judge, Delhi.
Decree upheld in Second Appeal by single Judge of Punjab High Court, who modified salary figure but upheld main issues.
Letters Patent Appeal No. 36-D of 1963 summarily dismissed by Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi on April 11, 1963.
Ex. D-5: Certificate that Diwanchand Bhatia received charge as Officiating Deputy Superintendent of Police, Enforcement, Delhi on forenoon of 28th April 1949.
Ex. D-4: Order of Inspector-General of Police, Delhi dated June 6, 1949 posting Diwanchand Bhatia to city vice Malik Bodh Raj, DSP Enforcement.
Diwanchand Bhatia testified he took charge as per documents and conducted enquiry.
Diwanchand Bhatia received application from Jagannath SP for enquiry, conducted preliminary enquiry, found prima facie case, sent to District Magistrate who approved departmental enquiry.
File relating to departmental enquiry destroyed under Police Rule 12.35 by order of Abdul Rehman on 15th January 1953, per Ex. D-2.
Jagannath was Superintendent of Police, City, with charge over police stations including Faiz Bazar where respondent posted.
Delhi area including New Delhi, Old Delhi, rural areas under one District Magistrate; police under Inspector-General with two Superintendents: one for Delhi City, one for New Delhi.

legal_issues.text: Whether the dismissal was illegal because the officer entrusted with departmental enquiry (Diwanchand Dhatia) was not a police officer.
Whether the order of dismissal passed by Shri Jagannath was invalid because he was not a District Superintendent of Police.
Whether the dismissal was void on account of non-compliance with Rule 16.38 of the Punjab Police Rules.

petitioner_arguments.text: Jagannath, functioning as Superintendent of Police (not designated District SP), was competent to pass dismissal order under Police Act and Punjab Police Rules.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Police Act 1861 ss. 1, 2, 3, 4, 7; Punjab Police Rules 1934 rr. 11, 12, 13, 14, 16.1

petitioner_arguments.text: Diwanchand Bhatia was a police officer (Deputy SP Enforcement) superior to Sub-Inspector, competent to conduct enquiry.
Rule 16.38 complied with: preliminary enquiry done, prima facie case sent to District Magistrate who approved departmental enquiry.

respondent_arguments.text: Diwanchand Bhatia not a police officer as he had retired and was re-employed only in Enforcement Department.
Jagannath not competent as he was not designated District Superintendent of Police.
No compliance with Rule 16.38: no evidence of informing District Magistrate or his decision for departmental enquiry; strict compliance mandatory.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Punjab Police Rules 1934 r. 16.38; State of UP v. Babu Ram; Delhi Admin v. Chanan Shah

court_reasoning.text: No difference between 'Superintendent of Police' in Rules and 'District Superintendent of Police' in Act; Jagannath as SP City competent over relevant police station.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Police force expanded post-1861; multiple SPs possible per district; Act and Rules read together.

court_reasoning.text: Diwanchand Bhatia was Deputy SP Enforcement (police department), superior to Sub-Inspector, hence police officer competent to enquire.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Enforcement merely specifies department; re-employment as DSP confirmed by documents and testimony.

court_reasoning.text: Testimony of Diwanchand Bhatia accepted: preliminary steps under R.16.38 followed, DM approved; no issue framed below, file destroyed lawfully.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Substantial compliance even if directory; no reason to disbelieve witness.

holdings.text: Superintendent of Police equivalent to District Superintendent of Police for dismissal powers.
Re-employed DSP Enforcement is a police officer competent to conduct enquiry against Sub-Inspector.
Compliance with Rule 16.38 established by evidence.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh and others v. Babu Ram
precedents_cited.relevance: Police Act and Rules constitute self-contained code; strict compliance for dismissal.
No departure from rules; even if directory, substantial compliance needed for Rule 16.38.

statutes_cited.name: Police Act, 1861
statutes_cited.relevance: Vesting of police administration; appointment, dismissal powers of District Superintendents.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Police Rules, 1934
statutes_cited.relevance: Police districts, command structure, punishments, enquiry procedure, destruction of records.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Subject to provisions for dismissal of inferior officers.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgments and orders of courts below set aside; suit filed by respondent dismissed.
outcome.relief_granted: Dismissal of suit upholding validity of respondent's dismissal from service.
outcome.costs: No order as to costs of this appeal; previous order for costs not disturbed (special leave granted on condition appellant pays respondent's costs).

key_quotes.text: "In our opinion, there is no difference between 'Superintendent of Police' in the Rules and 'District Superintendent of Police' in the Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Resolves competency of Jagannath to dismiss.

key_quotes.text: "We see no force in this contention as the Enforcement Department was still a police department and a Deputy Superintendent of Police Enforcement was still a Deputy Superintendent of Police."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Confirms Diwanchand Bhatia as police officer.

key_quotes.text: "We see no reason to disbelieve the testimony of Diwanchand Bhatia."
key_quotes.speaker: court
